persons.name: Moses
persons.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: RichardPayne Knight
persons.description: Presumably this pencil addition refers to Richard Payne Knight the classical scholar, who in 1824 bequeathed a bronze helmet of Corinthian type to the British Museum.

persons.name: Paracelsus
persons.description: Born Theophrastus von Hohenheim Swiss physician, alchemist, lay theologian, and philosopher of the German Renaissance.

persons.name: AthanasiusKircher
persons.description: Prolific German Jesuit scholar and polymath who published many book, including on geology.

places.name: Corinth
places.description: Ancient Corinth was one of the largest and most important cities of Greece. The modern city of Corinth is located approximately 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northeast of the ancient ruins.

persons.name: Strabo
persons.description: Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.

places.name: Phrygia
places.description: In classical antiquity, Phrygia was a kingdom in the west central part of Anatolia, in what is now Asian Turkey, centered on the Sangarios River.

persons.name: Martial
persons.description: Roman poet born in Hispania (modern Spain) best known for his twelve books of Epigrams, published in Rome between AD 86 and 103.

persons.name: SmithsonTennant
persons.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HennigBrand
persons.description: German alchemist who accidentally discovered phosphorus.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilhelmHisinger
persons.description: Swedish physicist and chemist who collaborated with Jöns Jacob Berzelius.

persons.name: Anders GustafEkeberg
persons.description: Swedish analytical chemist who discovered tantalum in 1802.

persons.name: WilliamGregor
persons.description: Cornish clergyman and mineralogist who discovered the elemental metal titanium. Knew Davy.

persons.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
persons.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: Peter JacobHjelm
persons.description: Swedish chemist and the first person to isolate the element molybdenum (1781).

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertBingley
persons.description: Assay Master of the Royal Mint in London

persons.name: JuliusCaesar
persons.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Alexander III
persons.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

persons.name: DiodorusSiculus
persons.description: Of Sicily was an ancient Greek historian. He is known for writing the monumental universal history Bibliotheca historica, in forty books, fifteen of which survive intact, between 60 and 30 BCE.

places.name: Mount's Bay
places.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: St Michael's Mount
places.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: Theophrastus
persons.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: John JoachimBecher
persons.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: GeorgeRipley
persons.description: English Augustinian canon, author, and alchemist.

persons.name: RamonLlull
persons.description: Catalonian philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.
